sentences.sentence: This is a story about something that happened long ago when your grandfather was a child.
It is a very important story because it shows how all the comings and goings between our own world and the land of Narnia first began.
In those days Mr. Sherlock Holmes was still living in Baker Street( 贝克街，地名 ) and the Bastables were looking for treasure in the Lewisham Road.
In those days, if you were a boy you had to wear a stiff( 硬邦邦的 ) Eton collar every day, and schools were usually nastier( 更令人讨厌的 ) than now. But meals were nicer;
and as for sweets, I won’t tell you how cheap and good they were, because it would only make your mouth water in vain( 徒然地 ).
And in those days there lived in London a girl called Polly Plummer.
She lived in one of a long row of houses which were all joined together.
One morning she was out in the back garden when a boy scrambled( 爬 ) up from the garden next door and put his face over the wall.
Polly was very surprised because up till now there had never been any children in that house,
but only Mr. Ketterley and Miss Ketterley, a brother and sister, old bachelor( 单身汉 ) and old maid( 未婚女子 ), living together.
So she looked up, full of curiosity.
The face of the strange boy was very grubby( 脏兮兮的 ).
It could hardly have been grubbier( 更加脏兮兮的 ) if he had first rubbed( 搓 ) his hands in the earth, and then had a good cry, and then dried his face with his hands.
As a matter of fact, this was very nearly what he had been doing.
“Hullo,” said Polly.
“Hullo,” said the boy. “What’s your name?”
“Polly,” said Polly. “What’s yours?”
“Digory,” said the boy.
“I say, what a funny name!” said Polly.
“It isn’t half so funny as Polly,” said Digory.
“Yes it is,” said Polly.
“No, it isn’t,” said Digory.
“At any rate I do wash my face,” said Polly, “which is what you need to do; especially after—” and then she stopped.
She had been going to say “After you’ve been blubbing( 哭哭啼啼 ),” but she thought that wouldn’t be polite.
“All right, I have then,” said Digory in a much louder voice, like a boy who was so miserable( 伤心的 ) that he didn’t care who knew he had been crying.
“And so would you,” he went on, “if you’d lived all your life in the country and had a pony( 小马驹 ), and a river at the bottom of the garden,
and then been brought to live in a beastly( 糟糕的 ) Hole like this.”
“London isn’t a Hole,” said Polly indignantly( 愤怒地 ). But the boy was too wound up( 激动的 ) to take any notice of her, and he went on—

“And if your father was away in India—and you had to come and live with an Aunt and an Uncle who’s mad (who would like that?)—and if the reason was that they were looking after your Mother—and if your Mother was ill and was going to—going to—die.”
Then his face went the wrong sort of shape as it does if you’re trying to keep back your tears.
“I didn’t know. I’m sorry,” said Polly humbly( 惭愧地 ).
And then, because she hardly knew what to say, and also to turn Digory’s mind to cheerful subjects, she asked:
“Is Mr. Ketterley really mad?”
“Well either he’s mad,” said Digory, “or there’s some other mystery( 秘密 ).
He has a study on the top floor and Aunt Letty says I must never go up there.
Well, that looks fishy( 可疑的 ) to begin with. And then there’s another thing.
Whenever he tries to say anything to me at meal times—he never even tries to talk to her—she always shuts him up( 让...闭嘴 ).
She says, ‘Don’t worry the boy, Andrew’ or ‘I’m sure Digory doesn’t want to hear about that’ or else ‘Now, Digory, wouldn’t you like to go out and play in the garden?’ ”
“What sort of things does he try to say?”
“I don’t know. He never gets far enough. But there’s more than that.
One night—it was last night in fact—as I was going past the foot of the attic-stairs( 阁楼楼梯 ) on my way to bed (and I don’t much care for going past them either) I’m sure I heard a yell( 叫喊 ).”
“Perhaps he keeps a mad wife shut up( 关 ) there.”
“Yes, I’ve thought of that.”
“Or perhaps he’s a coiner( 伪币制造者 ).”
“Or he might have been a pirate( 海盗 ), like the man at the beginning of Treasure Island( 金银岛，书名 ), and be always hiding from his old shipmates.”
“How exciting!” said Polly. “I never knew your house was so interesting.”
“You may think it interesting,” said Digory. “But you wouldn’t like it if you had to sleep there.
How would you like to lie awake listening for Uncle Andrew’s step to come creeping( 悄悄穿过 ) along the passage to your room?
And he has such awful eyes.”
That was how Polly and Digory got to know one another:
and as it was just the beginning of the summer holidays and neither of them was going to the sea that year, they met nearly every day.
Their adventures began chiefly because it was one of the wettest and coldest summers there had been for years.
That drove them to do indoor things: you might say, indoor exploration.
It is wonderful how much exploring you can do with a stump( 一节 ) of candle in a big house, or in a row of houses.

Polly had discovered long ago that if you opened a certain little door in the box-room attic( 阁楼 ) of her house you would find the cistern( 水箱 ) and a dark place behind it which you could get into by a little careful climbing.
The dark place was like a long tunnel( 隧道 ) with brick wall on one side and sloping( 倾斜的 ) roof on the other.
In the roof there were little chunks( 大量 ) of light between the slates( 石板 ).
There was no floor in this tunnel( 隧道 ): you had to step from rafter( 椽子 ) to rafter( 椽子 ), and between them there was only plaster( 灰泥 ).
If you stepped on this you would find yourself falling through the ceiling( 天花板 ) of the room below.
Polly had used the bit of the tunnel( 隧道 ) just beside the cistern( 蓄水池 ) as a smugglers( 走私者 )’ cave.
She had brought up bits of old packing cases and the seats of broken kitchen chairs,
and things of that sort, and spread them across from rafter( 椽子 ) to rafter( 椽子 ) so as to make a bit of floor.
Here she kept a cash-box containing various treasures, and a story she was writing and usually a few apples.
She had often drunk a quiet bottle of ginger-beer in there: the old bottles made it look more like a smugglers( 走私者 )’ cave.
Digory quite liked the cave (she wouldn’t let him see the story) but he was more interested in exploring.
“Look here,” he said. “How long does this tunnel( 隧道 ) go on for? I mean, does it stop where your house ends?”
“No,” said Polly. “The walls don’t go out to the roof. It goes on. I don’t know how far.”
“Then we could get the length of the whole row of houses.”
“So we could,” said Polly. “And oh, I say!”
“What?”
“We could get into the other houses.”
“Yes, and get taken up for burglars( 强盗 )! No thanks.”
“Don’t be so jolly( 非常 ) clever. I was thinking of the house beyond yours.”
“What about it?”
“Why, it’s the empty one. Daddy says it’s always been empty ever since we came here.”
“I suppose we ought to have a look at it then,” said Digory.
He was a good deal( 很多 ) more excited than you’d have thought from the way he spoke.
For of course he was thinking, just as you would have been, of all the reasons why the house might have been empty so long.
So was Polly. Neither of them said the word “haunted( 闹鬼的 ).”
And both felt that once the thing had been suggested, it would be feeble( 软弱的 ) not to do it.
“Shall we go and try it now?” said Digory.
“All right,” said Polly.
“Don’t if you’d rather not,” said Digory.
“I’m game if you are,” said she.
“How are we to know we’re in the next house but one?”
They decided they would have to go out into the box-room and walk across it taking steps as long as the steps from one rafter( 椽子 ) to the next.
That would give them an idea of how many rafters( 椽子 ) went to a room.
Then they would allow about four more for the passage between the two attics( 阁楼 ) in Polly’s house, and then the same number for the maid( 女佣 )’s bedroom as for the box-room.
That would give them the length of the house.
When they had done that distance twice they would be at the end of Digory’s house;
any door they came to after that would let them into an attic( 阁楼 ) of the empty house.
“But I don’t expect it’s really empty at all,” said Digory.
“What do you expect?”
“I expect someone lives there in secret, only coming in and out at night, with a dark lantern.
We shall probably discover a gang( 一群 ) of desperate( 绝望的 ) criminals and get a reward.
It’s all rot( 胡扯 ) to say a house would be empty all those years unless there was some mystery( 秘密 ).”
“Daddy thought it must be the drains( 下水管道 ),” said Polly.
“Pooh( 噗 )! Grown-ups( 成年人 ) are always thinking of uninteresting explanations,” said Digory.
Now that they were talking by daylight in the attic( 阁楼 ) instead of by candlelight in the Smugglers( 走私者 )’ Cave it seemed much less likely that the empty house would be haunted( 闹鬼的 ).

article_info.previous: 朽骨暗夜候多时。误入的冒险者，沉睡千年的魔咒，已被你唤醒……

article_info.share_words: This is a story about something that happened long ago when your grandfather was a child. It a very important story because it shows how all the comings and goings between our own world and the land of Narnia first began.

question.cn: Polly认为男孩的名字怎么样？
question.en: What did Polly think of the boy’s name?

analysis: 文中Polly知道了男孩儿的名字叫Digory，她马上说道：“I say, what a funny name!”因此选A。

question.cn: 根据Digory的叙述，他的爸爸在哪里？
question.en: According to Digory, where was his father?

analysis: 文中Digory提到：“If your father was away in India. . . ”因此知道Digory的父亲远在印度，所以选B。

question.cn: Polly和Digory是什么时候成为朋友的？
question.en: When did Polly and Digory become friends?

options.en: At the end of the winter holiday.
At the beginning of the summer holiday.
At the beginning of the winter holiday.

analysis: 文中提到：“That was how Polly and Digory got to know one another: and as it just the beginning of the summer holidays. . . ”此处可以知道两人是在暑假开始的时候认识彼此并且成为朋友的，因此选B。

question.en: Why did Polly and Digory begin their adventures?

options.en: Because they were in a good mood.

analysis: 文中提到：“There adventures began chiefly because it was one of the wettest and coldest summers there had been for years. That drove them to do indoor things: you may say, indoor exploration.”由此可知，Polly和Digory开始探险的原因是由于那年夏天的天气十分潮湿和阴冷，所以他们才进行室内探险，因此选A。

question.cn: Digory期待空屋的阁楼上有什么？
question.en: What did Digory expect in the attic of the empty house?

options.cn: 他认为阁楼里满是怪物。
options.en: He thought that it was full of monsters.

options.cn: 他认为阁楼上空无一人。
options.en: He thought that it was empty.

options.cn: 他认为有人秘密居住在阁楼。
options.en: He thought that someone lived there secretly.

analysis: 文中提到当Polly问道：“What do you expect from?”Digory答道：“I expect someone lives there in secret, only coming in and out at night, with a dark lantern. . . ”由此可知，Digory认为空屋子的阁楼上有人秘密地住在那里，因此选C。
